title: How Does the Weather Affect Allergies?

content: If you have seasonal allergies, you might have noticed that your symptoms get worse – or better – depending on the weather. That runny nose , congestion, and sneezing are a reaction to things like pollens, molds, and dust. You might come across more of them depending on what’s happening outside. “Weather can impact seasonal allergies by the way it affects the spread of allergens,” says Michele Pham, MD, an allergist and immunologist at University of California San Francisco Health. “The weather also changes the way we behave, so that can affect our exposure level to allergens as well.”

sections.heading: Wind
content: Windy days can have a big impact on allergies, says Navid Ziaie, MD, assistant professor of medicine specializing in allergy and clinical immunology at Oregon Health and Science University School of Medicine. “Wind really helps pollen mobilize and travel from the source of the allergen to our respiratory system , into our sinuses and into our lungs ,” he says. “Wind can stir up dust, it can stir up pollen, it can stir up mold spores that can activate your allergies.” Pollen can travel far from its source in the wind. “The wind can bring cedar pollen or ragweed pollen hundreds of miles away to your nose,” Pham says.

sections.heading: Humidity and Rain
content: Moisture in the air can have different impacts depending on your specific allergies. Rain can help wash away allergens in the air, but it can also promote growth of molds, Pham says. Similarly, humidity can make dust and mold worse. But it can also keep pollen weighed down and on the ground. Dry weather without rain can mean higher pollen counts as allergens blow around. Weather also affects the severity of the next allergy season. A wet and rainy fall and winter can lead to more pollination in the spring and summer, Ziaie says.

sections.heading: Temperature
content: Whether it's a frigid or warm day makes a difference in how you’ll spend it and therefore what allergens you’ll face. “In the cold, people tend to stay indoors more, so they get more exposure to indoor mold, dust and pet dander,” Pham says. On sunny spring and summer days, people with allergies spend more time outside enjoying the weather, even when pollen counts are high.

sections.heading: Thunderstorms
content: The wind, rain, and humidity combined in a thunderstorm have been known to cause worsened allergy symptoms , Pham says. “All of those forces can make pollen burst and disperse into really tiny particles that can reach your sinuses and into your lungs more easily,” she says. “The strong winds can spread them really far as well.”

sections.heading: How to Cope
content: When allergens are active, try these tips to limit their impact: Keep your house and car windows closed. Use air conditioning instead. Wear a hat and sunglasses when outside to protect your face from pollen. Wear a mask outside. Shower and change clothes after being outside. Check pollen counts online or in the newspaper and plan accordingly. Use an air purifier. Over-the-counter medications like oral or nasal spray antihistamines can help. If you have consistent symptoms, try to take medication before they start or before spending time outside, Pham says. There are a lot of options, so work with your doctor to find the best regimen, she says. See an allergist to be allergy tested. Finding out which specific types of pollen or substances you are allergic to will help you avoid them directly.

sections.heading: Remember the Season
content: “There are established pollen seasons when no matter what the weather is, there are going to be plants pollinating that can cause allergies,” Ziaie says. “Weather can influence how bad pollen is on a day-to-day or week-to-week basis, but regardless of the weather there is going to be pollen around.” In the United States, spring allergy season begins in February and can last into early summer with tree and grass pollens. Fall is ragweed pollen season. Winter brings problems with indoor allergens like molds and dust mites .

sections.heading: When It’s Not Allergies
content: Changes in weather as well as barometric pressure can cause allergy symptoms, even if you don’t have allergies. That’s called vasomotor or non-allergic rhinitis. You can also have these sensitivities along with allergies, Pham says. “A lot of people with allergies can also have non-allergic triggers as well,” she says. “They can get irritation from the wind, from humidity, from harsh temperatures like really hot weather or really cold weather, and so that on top of having allergies can also make symptoms overall worse.” Saline sprays and medicated decongestant and antihistamine nasal sprays can help with this kind of inflammation and congestion.

meta_description: The weather can make your seasonal allergies worse. Wind and storms stir up pollen. Find out how to avoid it and treat your symptoms.
